awd_titl_txt: Assessing the changes in the brain representations of individual STEM concepts in the course of learning
awd_abstract_narration:
Discovering how STEM concepts are represented in the brain will allow us to both assess student learning of science and to teach STEM concepts more effectively. This project makes use of previous work by the investigators that demonstrated the remarkable new ability to determine the neural correlates (brain signature) of an individual concept, using fMRI brain imaging. Knowing the brain signature of physics concepts like gravity and velocity makes it possible to observe how the brain representations develop in a learner's brain, how they are organized, and how they depend on that person's learning background and on the teaching method. If we know the brain's way of organizing STEM concept knowledge, we can design curricula that teach to that organizational system and measure student learning at the brain level. This approach will not replace conventional tests, but it will provide a new type of basis for those tests such that they can assess alternative instructional methods. 

 The investigators had previously shown that neural signatures can be decomposed into meaningful underlying dimensions that are remarkably similar across people, making it possible to precisely compare the neural representations of student learners to the representations of instructors or of other successful learners. What has not been attempted before, and is the major goal of this project, is relating the neural signatures of concept learning to various learning outcomes.  Behavioral tests will assess the students? acquisition of the concepts and fMRI scans will assess the acquisition of the concomitant brain representations of the individual concepts.  The students' neural representations will be analyzed for their intrinsic integrity, measured by a machine learning classifier's accuracy in identifying a concept from its fMRI signature.  These will be compared to the neural representations of people with demonstrated mastery of the concepts (such as advanced students and the class instructors). Additionally, the project will assess changes in brain tissues (gray and white matter) that co-occur with concept learning, as well as changes in synchronization (functional connectivity) between brain regions involved in the concept representations. A central contribution of this project will be a brain-based understanding of how individual scientific concepts are learned and how this learning can be related to behavioral measures and individual differences.  The long-term goal is to build the foundation for neuroscience findings to inform teaching techniques and assessments, and as inspiration for additional strategies to promote successful learning in both the general student population and students at risk for failure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project demonstrated that neural (fMRI) measures are predictive of students' behavioral measures of achievement in college-level physics.  Equally important was the discovery that the neural measures indicated which psychological processes were largely responsible for the achievement. Specifically, the similarity of students' neural representations of physics concepts to those of the instructors was a strong predictor of a behavioral measure of physics learning (the Hestenes' Force Concept Inventory - FCI), even more so than were other behavioral measures of ability, such as a test of fluid intelligence (Raven Progressive Matrices Test). The experimental procedures and analyses developed and used here indicate neural assessments can be used as a multi-component neural index of learning to measure academic success. The research consisted of a set of empirical studies that used fMRI to assess the learning of individual STEM concepts in physics and related neural assessments to behavioral measures of educational outcomes. The classroom instruction occurred in college introductory physics classes. The fMRI data was analyzed using a machine learning approach that leveraged the ability to train a classifier on a set of expert (instructor) brain images and then test the student brain images against that classifier resulting in identification of representations most like instructors. The data was condensed using a factor analysis technique that extracted the underlying dimensions of neural representation across concepts. We anticipate this educational neuroscience approach can be used across STEM fields such as biology, mathematics, and chemistry.

The key pioneering discovery was the predictive relation uncovered between students' neural organization of physics concepts and a behavioral measure of physics learning. What makes this discovery impactful is that it allowed us to identify processes (knowledge management) and representations (unsystematic motion) that drove the correlation between academic outcome (FCI) and the similarity of a student's neural representation to instructors' neural representations.  This potentially enables an instructional focus on the knowledge management process (underpinned by medial frontal brain regions). Knowledge management involves the integration of several propositions worth of information about a phenomenon. It has long been known that the component propositions (or more precisely, the spatial, temporal, and causal relations they refer to) each have to be understood in order to master the concept. What is evident here is the centrality of the ability to integrate or manage these individual components of the information. Thus, the potential impact on physics instruction is a focus on knowledge integration, ensuring that during instruction the relations among the properties of a concept are understood and learned. The second manner in which the higher scoring students more closely resembled the instructors was the representation of unsystematic motion. Concepts with unsystematic motion are processed as unpredictable by both students and instructors. What the better students learn is the predictability of motion; their learned neural representations of concepts of systematic motion are more similar to instructors' representations at both ends of the dimension (systematic and unsystematic).  The students who score lower in the FCI may not have developed as nuanced representations of motion predictability.

The project had broader impacts in several ways.  First a multidisciplinary collaboration was developed between Physics and Psychology Departments and a large set of freshman physics students received real world experience in human subject research and MRI. Specifically a collaboration was formed with members of the physics department and the psychology department at Carnegie Mellon University.  The collaboration involved: (1) discussions of how physics was taught to undergraduates; (2) the inclusion of physics students in behavioral research; and, (3) a research project in which the physics faculty were the participants.  Results from this project have appeared in popular media, such as CNET and Discover magazine which described how advanced scientific education transforms human brains. This project demonstrates that the use of machine-learning methods can be done productively in educational evaluation. Too often students have poor test performance that does not reflect on their knowledge of a topic but rather on their ability to perform under pressure, to understand the questions, to correctly demonstrate their knowledge or even the teacher's ability to express the question.  The potential to assess performance with fMRI may remove some of the performance barriers of traditional testing methods.
